Examples

MyRightCareer Insights These five documents are examples of the insights Casey obtained from completing all the exercises: Begin at the End, Autobiography, Accomplishments, Personality, Interests, Strengths, Skills, Stories, Drivers, How Will You Measure Your Life and Fuel Your Economic Engine. From these examples you can see how insights were added with every exercise. Some of the insights might be the same, just stated in a slightly different way. Or you can have the exact same insights used in multiple circles. In fact that is what you want to see. Then you start to pick up some themes. Click on the links below to see the documents.
Casey's "Be Your Best" Insights Casey's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Casey's "Economic Engine" Insights Casey's "Right Career" Insights Casey's "Whole Person" Insights

Update your MyRightCareer Insights Documents

Take your existing MyRightCareer Insights documents and add the insights you have gained from this exercise. Remember you only have one file for each of the four circles in the Venn diagram and then a fifth file for the Whole Person. You do not create new MyRightCareer Insights files for each exercise. Instead you are adding insights on top of the insights from the previous exercise. Within each file are the headings for the Exercises to make this easy. You can see this by looking at Casey’s examples above. Be sure to add insights to each of the documents: - Be Your Best: The first question should help with this insight area (How can I be sure I will be successful and happy in my career?) - Meaning & Passion: The second and third questions should provide insights for this area (How can I be sure that my relationships with my spouse, my children, my extended family and close friends become an enduring source of happiness? How can I live a life of integrity — and stay out of jail?) - Fuel your Economic Engine: The first question should help with this insight area (How can I be sure I will be successful and happy in my career?). How much of that is measured in dollars? The second question should provide insights for this area (How can I be sure that my relationships with my spouse, my children, my extended family and close friends become an enduring source of happiness?) - they provide happiness but they also require financial resources. The third question should provide insights for this area (How can I live a life of integrity — and stay out of jail?) If you don't stay out of jail you will not provide much fuel. - Right Opportunities: Doesn't a Right Opportunity allow you to answer all three questions? - Whole Person: All three questions have Whole Person ramifications.

item.title: Feedback-Meaning+Passion
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This survey is providing feedback for the entire Meaning Assignment, not just the Meaning Insights Exercise. We making changes to the MyRightCareer Program and Web site in almost real time so your timely feedback is very important. Students coming after you will benefit from it.
Most of the feedback in this survey asks you to agree or disagree with a statement. You have five levels of agreement: Strongly Disagree, Disagree, Neutral, Agree, Strongly Agree.
Besides that you will have a chance to provide free form textual input.
Create your free online surveys with SurveyMonkey , the world's leading questionnaire tool.

item.title: 3 - Program Approach
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

You may identify your Right Career or Careers after completing only three of the Insights Assignments. It just all falls together and you say "Yes, that is what I should be doing". This can happen no matter which of the two approaches described below, College Course or Cafeteria, you choose. The Assignments (and the Exercises within them) are not going to magically tell you what is your Right Career.
You are going to start to recognize that through Intuition. The diagram at the left graphically shows you start out with the emphasis heavily on Analysis. As you finish the Assignments across the bottom your Intuition should be taking over.      

Course Approach

A good way to start is to envision the MyRightCareer Program as a college course. If you click on Program Schedule you will get a pdf file showing the recommend order for the Assignments and a suggested time line. The recommended order for completing the Assignments is their position across the top of the Web page. Some of the later Exercises require information generated in the earlier exercises, e.g. to complete the Age 30 Budget Exercise you need your Age 30 Vision from the Begin at the End Exercise. It is recommended you follow a 12 week schedule for completing the MyRightCareer Program, assuming you want to finish quickly. The Program is totally self-paced so you can determine your own schedule - you can finish it in less elapsed time or take longer. The 12 week schedule made the following assumptions:
  • 1 week for Prerequisites
  • 8 weeks for six Insights Assignments (average of 4.7 hours/week)
  • 3 weeks for Capstone Project (average of 3.3 hours/week)
    The bulk of the work is completing the six Insights Assignments which contain 13 Exercises. Each Exercise takes about 3 hours to complete. Each Exercise has multiple Steps and no Step is longer than 1 hour so you can work on this in 1 hour or shorter increments. You may find you can finish the Exercises faster than I estimated and thus finish the entire Program sooner than my 12 week schedule.
    If you click on Program Schedule Template - Excel you will get the Excel version. It is the sample schedule, except in Excel so you can create your own schedule. It uses movable red boxes to represent the schedule.You can move the red boxes around - there are one week, two week and three week boxes.

    Cafeteria Approach

    You don't have to do the Assignments in the recommended order, instead you can complete the ones that you feel will provide the most insights. You might feel the following are the most important for you: Future (Begin at the End), Self (Personality & Interests) and Strengths (Skills & Talents/Strengths). If you do them out of order you may find you are missing some pre-requisite exercises (e.g. to complete the Age 30 Budget Exercise you need your Age 30 Vision from the Begin at the End Assignment). There is a simple solution to this problem. In the instructions for the Exercises where this problem occurs, there will be guidance for fulfilling the pre-requisite. Once you feel you have identified your Right Career or Career (s) you should move on to the Capstone Assignment where you will:
  • Document that Right Career
  • Validate your Right Career Choice (s)
  • Build a Sales Story
  • Create a Follow-on Plan
    If you did not do all of the Assignments there are good reasons to finish them. In the above example the other 3 Insights Assignments allow you:
  • To validate the Right Career you identified after your first 3 Insights Assignments is still the right one for you
  • To build a more compelling Sales Story, e.g. in this example: Past (an Autobiography & Accomplishments – useful for Sales Story), Meaning (useful for Sales Story) and Economics (puts some financial reality into your ideas)
  • To put some financial reality into your ideas, e.g. Fuel your Economic Engine (Age 30 Budget, Age 22 Budget and Age 22 Non-Professional Budget)

    Summary

    No matter how you used the MyRightCareer resources - going through the Program in the recommended order or just doing the Assignments you see as valuable - you should be able to identify your Right Career, Build a compelling Sales Story and Create a Follow-on Plan.

item.title: 5- Benefits
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

There are two types of benefits from taking the MyRightCareer Program:

  • Immediate

    This is what you get once you take that first step on your Right Career path. It is the benefit of being in your Right Career.

  • Long Term

    This is how the Program will help you as you move forward in your life. In today's world this is probably not the only time you will make a career decision. They are predicted to have five to eight careers in their professional life. For more detail click on the Long Term Benefits link in the Sub Navigation section on the right.

    Benefits Detail - Optional Exercise

    If you want to explore the Immediate and Long Term Benefits click on Benefits. This will launch the marketing Web site and take you to the Benefits page.

item.title: Old Content Strategy
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

The Content Strategy Internship requires you to improve the overall content strategy for the entire program. The improvement may take forms very similar to those of an individual exercise, but be designed to apply to all the exercises, e.g. instructions, examples, templates, exercise flow, Short vs. Full Instructions, general feedback, SurveyMonkey questions & feedback, other feedback, use of YouTube/video’s, use of Facebook,and many others. This area can include recommendations to add Exercises or drop Exercises.
Alternately you can contribute to the improvement of at least one Assignment (which usually contains two Exercises). The improvement can take many forms of improvements, e.g. instructions, examples, templates, exercise flow, Short vs. Full Instructions, general feedback, SurveyMonkey questions & feedback, other feedback, use of YouTube/video’s, use of Facebook,and many others.

Examples

Improve Content Strategy

You might decide to explore the Capstone Assignment and its relationship to the six Insights assignments. You might choose to examine how the student is able to glean insights into their Right Career from the six Insights assignments and try to develop a better way to do that.
You might explore how the use of YouTube video's could improve the exercises and how that approach could be implemented. This could include creating a sample video for one Exercise.

Improve an Assignment or Exercise

You might examine the "Begin at the End" exercise (one that requires the student to visualize them self at Age 30). Maybe you start with the SurveyMonkey feedback we have already received. You can use your own experience of taking that exercise. Maybe you take it over again, concentrating on ways it can be improved. You find out from Don some people who have taken that exercise and get permission to interview them. From all of this you start to explore ways to improve the exercise. You may come up with approaches that could apply across all of the exercises, as well as to the Begin at the End exercise, e.g. exercise flow, use of videos, types of examples.
You might choose an excise like Personality that uses the Myers-Briggs Personality Type and explore if there is a better way to leverage that standard test. You might explore all the other tests available in that same area, both from Myers-Briggs and from others in that area.

Background Needed

MyRightCareer Program:
To understand the MyRightCareer Program you must use it
  • Pre-Requisite Assignment
  • Begin at the End Assignment
  • Two Assignments (to be chosen in concert with Don Lundgren, the Program developer)
    You are welcome to use any of the six Insights Assignments. There are three more beyond the three required to gain a cursory understanding of the MyRightCareer Program.
    Web sites:
    High level understanding of Web-based content delivery Research sets of Web sites that are similar to MyRightCareer sites Willingness to learn
    Career Planning
    High level understanding of career planning Willingness to learn
    Skills
    Analysis Research

    What are the Next Step?

  • Optional - Learn more about the MyRightCareer Program: Visit the Prerequisites page. It provides more detail on items such as: MyRightCareer Program, Right Career Concept, Program Approaches (College Course vs. Cafeteria), Program Content (Assignments & Exercises) and Benefits.
  • Choosing Your Internship: Click on the SN tab at the top menu, this will produce a complete menu. This approach will allow you to navigate to any Internship.
  • Contact Don: To request an Internship send your resume and a cover email explaining which Internship you would like and what you feel you will gain from that Internship to Don at Don@My-Right-Career.com

item.title: 6 - Program User - Adviser & CAB
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

You have an opportunity to get assistance from experienced adults to help you find your right career. One where your are being your best because the role plays to your strengths and personality. One where your find meaning and passion in your role and the company's mission. One where you are willing to work 24/7, but it is not really work to you. In that right career you provide a lot of the creative energy in your department. Your enthusiasm is contagious. It doesn't matter if you are a college student, a recent graduate or an experienced adult using the MyRightCareer System. Almost every major change you try to make in your life (e.g. lose weight, get into better physical shape) has a higher chance of success if you involve others. That assistance can be provided via two roles: Adviser and/or Career Advisory Board Member. Both of them are described below. At the minimum we recommend you recruit a Career Advisory Board.

Adviser

As an Adviser they are more involved than they would be if they were a member of the your Career Advisory Board. As an Adviser they work with your on every Assignment, reviewing output from every Exercise in that Assignment. You will typically meet with them seven times, once for each of the six Insights Assignments and then once after the Capstone Assignment. Most of those reviews will take place over the phone and much of the content will be shared via email. Visit the Adviser. It provides more detail on items such as: What Does an Adviser Do?, What Support are Advisers Provided? and Can an Adviser use MyRightCareer for themselves? If you understand the Adviser Role it will be easy to understand the Career Advisory Board Member role.

Career Advisory Board Member

The Career Advisory Board probably never meets as a group. Instead you will meet with each member individually. Most of those meetings will take place over the phone and much of the content will be shared via email. As a Career Advisory Board Member their main role is reviewing output at three different points in the Program: 1st review will be after first three Insights Assignments, 2nd review will be after final three Insights Assignments and the Final Review will be after the Capstone project. Thus they will only be reviewing your work twice during the program so they are a lot less involved than an Adviser. Visit the Career Advisory Board. It provides more detail on items such as: What Does a Board Member Do?, What Support are Members Provided? and Can a Board Member use MyRightCareer for themselves?

Your Mentors can use this approach

The MyRightCareer Program is repurposed from the MyPlanB Program Don has been running for several years for people in their 30's, 40's, 50's and 60's. There will be an example of a person more like them for every exercise, along with guidance on how to use that exercise for their life.

item.title: 7 - Mentor - Adviser & CAB
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Note: This is written for the adult who the MyRightCareer Program User wants as a mentor (either as an Adviser or as a Career Advisory Board Member). As you think about your own department, division and company wouldn't you want a bunch of employees who were working at their right careers? Your department would be the most productive and creative department in the company. Your company would be the most productive, profitable and innovative company in the industry. It doesn't matter if they are a college student, a recent graduate or an experienced adult using the MyRightCareer System. Almost every major change you try to make in your life (e.g. lose weight, get into better physical shape) has a higher chance of success if you involve others. In your role as a career mentor you can help them in one of two roles: Adviser or Career Advisory Board Member. Both of them are described below. We suggest you focus on the Adviser role for the moment. Once you understand that role it will be easy to understand the difference between being an Adviser and a member of the students Career Advisory Board.

Adviser

As an Adviser you are more involved than you would be if you were a member of the Program User's Career Advisory Board. As an Adviser you help them design their use of the MyRightCareer System, e.g. which Assignments to complete and the schedule for the work. As an Adviser you work with them on every Insights Assignment they choose to complete. Most of those reviews will take place over the phone and much of the content will be shared via email. In the Adviser role you are hands-on, helping them as they move through the MyRightCareer process.
Visit

Adviser

It provides more detail on items such as: What Does an Adviser Do?, What Support are Advisers Provided? and Can an Adviser use MyRightCareer for themselves?

Career Advisory Board Member

The Career Advisory Board probably never meets as a group. Instead the Program User will meet with each member individually. Most of those meetings will take place over the phone and much of the content will be shared via email. As a Career Advisory Board Member your main role is reviewing output at two different points in the Program: 1st review will be after first three Insights Assignments, 2nd review will be after final three Insights Assignments. You will also have a Final Review after the Capstone project when they present their Right Opportunity, how they Validated it was really their Right Opportunity, their Sales Story and their Follow-on Plan. As a Career Advisory Board Member you are more removed from the MyRightCareer Process than an Adviser.
Visit

Career Advisory Board

It provides more detail on items such as: What Does a Board Member Do?, What Support are Members Provided? and Can a Board Member use MyRightCareer for themselves?

You can use this approach for Yourself

The MyRightCareer Program is repurposed from the MyPlanB Program Don has been running for several years for people in their 30's, 40's, 50's and 60's. There will be an example of a person more like you for every exercise, along with instructions on how to use that exercise for your life. In addition there will be other Experienced Adult examples on the Examples page.

What are the Next Steps?

  • Sign Up Talk to the MyRightCareer Program User who approached you, indicating if you are willing to be either an Adviser or a Career Advisory Board member (or both).
  • Optional - Learn more about the MyRightCareer Program: 1 ) Visit the Pre-Requisites page. It provides more detail on items such as: MyRightCareer Program, Right Career Concept, Program Approaches (College Course vs. Cafeteria), Program Content (Assignments & Exercises) and Benefits. 2) Vist the Home Page and you can look at any of the six Insights Assignments (containing 15 exercises), as well as the Capstone Assignment. They are listed across the top of the page and holding your cursor over the name will produce a drop down menu showing the Exercises and Steps within each exercise. You will notice the 1st Assignment is Pre-Requisites.
  • Optional - Contact Don: If you would like more information send an email to Don at Don@My-Right-Career.com

item.title: Adviser-Mentor
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

As an Adviser you are more involved than you would be if you were a member of the Program User's Career Advisory Board. As an Adviser you work with them on every Assignment.

What does an Adviser Do?

As the Adviser you have three roles.

Collaboratively Manage the Process:

First, the two of you manage the process (they drive it).
  • Together you decide on the approach the Program User should take: College Course or Cafeteria. If they use the College Course approach they will be completing all six Insight Assignments in the order they appear at the top of the screen. If the two of you choose the Cafeteria Approach you will select which of the six Assignments you feel would be most helpful in defining their right career. There is guidance in the PreRequisites Assignment, Course Approach module, for doing this. The Program User could start by doing only three Assignments and see if they can identify their right career. If after those three Assignments they don't feel ready to identify their right career you could then add one or two other Assignments you both think would add some more insights.
  • Together you set up the initial schedule. The two of you should create a schedule that takes into account how many Assignments, the student's academic, extracurricular (e.g. sports) and personal realities. It has to also factor your own schedule into the equation. This is entirely a self-paced Program. There is an Excel spreadsheet with a suggested schedule you two can customize.
  • There is a Checklist you will be given for each exercise that can be used by both of you to manage the progress.

Help with the Program Content:

Second, as an Adviser you can help them with the content of the Program, e.g. discussing how they are identifying their Top 10 Accomplishments. If you are using the MyRightCareer System for your own life and doing the Exercises in parallel with them it should be quite easy to have a dialogue about any exercise - sometimes they ask you for guidance and maybe sometimes you ask them for guidance.
  • Most of your involvement comes after they complete an Assignment and send you the completed exercises. The most important outputs are the MyRightCareer Insights files. There is one file for each of the circles in the Right Career Venn diagram: Be Your Best, Meaning & Passion, Economic Engine, Right Career (s) and Whole Person. After each exercise the student adds their insights for that exercise to each of the files. You should be reviewing those files after they complete each Assignment.
  • Most of those reviews will take place over the phone and much of the content will be shared via email.

Provide Feedback:

Third, the Adviser can help Don by providing feedback on the program.
  • Program User issues you observe, e.g. my Program User is having trouble summarizing the Assignment/Exercise information, they doesn't seem to be getting many insights, I think they found their Right Career after only three Assignments.
  • Adviser issues, e.g. if you provided me a tool for ABC it would make my job easier.
The Adviser can provide the feedback in two different ways: 1) via the Feedback page – there is a Feedback page on every Exercise that contains an on-line Survey, 2) Other – feel free to use whatever is easiest for you, e.g. email, phone.

Time Required

Program User

There are 15 Insights Exercises and 4 Capstone Exercises so the total time estimate for those 19 Exercises (using 2.5 hours/Assignment) is about 50 hours. That would most likely be spread over a 12 week period, but since the Program is entirely self-paced you and your student can work out a mutually acceptable schedule. Below is the logic for this estimate. If you and your student decide to use the Cafeteria approach and they only complete 3 of the 6 Insights Exercises both of you will invest less time. The amount of time invested nor the number of Assignments completed is not the issue. The goal is to identify the student's right career, validate it, create a sales story and build a follow-on plan.

Adviser

Your Program User will most likely ask you to review their exercise output after they complete each Assignment (which typically has two related Exercises, e.g Autobiography and Accomplishments). For every Exercise you will have two types of reviews.
  • Prior to the Assignment Review Session (1 hour): Review the exercise output your student sends you - you could take 1/2 hour to 1 1/2 hours reviewing their material.
  • During the Assignment Review Session (1 hour): This is most likely a phone call session - it could last from 1/2 hour to 1 1/2 hours.

What Support are Advisers Provided?

There will be information that will help the Adviser in two broad ways.

General Information:

There is general information such as this page. There are also scheduling and tracking resources. If you click on Program Schedule Template - pdf you will get the pdf version of a simple Excel scheduling tool. It has a sample that uses movable red boxes to represent the schedule. If you click on Program Schedule Template - Excel you will get the Excel version. It is the sample schedule, except in Excel so you can create your own schedule. You can move the red boxes around - there are one week, two week and three week boxes.

Exercise Specific Information:

There are specific resources for each exercise, e.g.
  • Experienced Adult Examples On the Adviser Guidance page there will be an Experienced Adult example so they can see an example more like themselves. In the Examples page there are other Experienced Adult examples.
  • Adviser Guidance on each exercise It will include an Introduction to the Exercise and the Steps the Adviser should be taking with the Program User. It is in the list of Steps for the Exercise and you can also click on any of those Steps to get a full set of Instructions. You can also click on the Short Instructions page for a single page with a few sentences, examples and templates for each Step. Click on Adviser Guidance - Begin at the End. and it will open in a new Tab. Once you have reviewed it you can close the Tab.
  • Exercise Checklist (used by both the Program User and Adviser). To see an example of a Checklist click on Begin at the End Checklist you will get the pdf document that is the Checklist for the sub-exercises in the Begin at the End Exercise. Each of you will have a copy of the same Checklist. There is the native Excel version of this file on the Templates page in the Begin at the End exercise Assignment

Future Adviser Support

Tools will be improved over time with feedback from the Adviser community. Some of the members may even contribute or suggest tools they have found useful.

How Can an Adviser Use this for Themselves?

You can use the MyRightCareer System just as your Advisee will be using it. You can complete the Pre-Requisite Assignment, the six Insights Assignments and finally the Capstone Assignment. Since the system is self-paced you can work on these Assignments (and exercises within each Assignment) at your own pace. The bulk of the work is completing the six Insights Assignments which contain 15 Exercises. Each Exercise takes about 2.5 hours to complete. Each Exercise has multiple Steps and no Step is longer than 1 hour so they can work on this in 1 hour or shorter increments. To use the system you can click on the Experienced Adult step at the end of each page. On that page is  guidance on how you can use this Exercise to identify their own Right Career, as well as an example of someone more like you. In the Examples page there are other examples of Experienced Adults. It will not be hard for you to dialogue with your Advisee when you have just finished the same Exercises applied to your life.

What are the Next Steps?

  • Optional - Learn more about the MyRightCareer Program: 1 ) Visit the Prerequisites page. It provides more detail on items such as: MyRightCareer Program, Right Career Concept, Program Approaches (College Course vs. Cafeteria), Program Content (Assignments & Exercises) and Benefits.2) Vist the Home Page and you can look at any of the six Insights Assignments (containing 13 exercises), as well as the Capstone Assignment. They are listed across the top of the page and holding your cursor over the name will produce a drop down menu showing the Exercises and Steps within each exercise.
  • Optional - Contact Don: If you would like more information send an email to Don at Don@My-Right-Career.com

item.title: Career Advisory Board-Mentor
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Unlike the Adviser, as a Career Advisory Board Member you will only be meeting with the MyRightCareer Program User three times during the program, not after each Assignment.

What Does a Board Member Do?

The Career Advisory Board (CAB) probably never meets as a group. Instead the Program User will meet with you individually. Most of those meetings will take place over the phone and much of the content will be shared via email.

Review Students Progress Three Times

A Career Advisory Board Member's main role is reviewing output at three different points in the Program. You only have to meet with your Program User twice during the actual program (CAB #1 and CAB #2):
  • Career Advisory Board Meeting #1 will be after they finish the first three Insights Assignments: Begin at the End, Look at Self (Personality and Interests) and Look at the Past (Autobiography and Accomplishments).
  • Career Advisory Board Meeting #2 will be after they finish the final three Insights Assignments: Strengths (Talents/Strengths and Skills), Meaning (Success Built to Last, Stories, Drivers, How you will Measure Your Life) and Economic Engine (Age 30 & Age 22).
  • Career Advisory Board Meeting #3 - Final Review will be after their Capstone project. They will have identified their Right Career (s), Validated it is really their Right Career, developed their Sales Story and created a Follow-on Plan.

Provide Feedback to Don

You can help Don by providing feedback on the program. You can provide the feedback in two areas:
  • Program User issues, e.g. they are having trouble summarizing the Assignment/Exercise information, they don't seem to be getting many insights, I think they found their Right Career by Career Advisory Board #1
  • Career Advisory Board issues, e.g. if you provided me a tool for ABC it would make my job easier.
You can provide the feedback in two different ways: 1) via the Feedback page – there is a Feedback page for every Career Advisory Board meeting (3 for the Program) that contains an on-line Survey, 2) Other – feel free to use whatever is easiest for you, e.g. email, phone.

Time Required

There are three Career Advisory Board Meetings and the total time estimate is about 12 hours. Below is the logic for this estimate. The first two Career Advisory Board Meeting will each be reviewing three Assignments. It is estimated you will spend about 4 hours per Meeting. For every Meeting you will have two types of reviews:
  • Prior to the Career Advisory Board Meeting (3 hour): Review the Assignment output they send you. You will probably spend about 1/2 hour per exercise and most Assignments have two exercises, so you will be reviewing six exercises which will take an estimated 3 hours.
  • During the Career Advisory Board Meeting (1 hour): This is most likely a phone call session with just you (not a meeting with the entire Board) and it could last from 1/2 hour to 1 1/2 hours.
The last Career Advisory Board Meeting occurs after the Capstone Assignment (identified their Right Career, developed their Sales Story and built a Follow-on Plan). You will have less to review before the Meeting but may have a longer meeting.

Career Advisory Board Member Support

There will be information that will help the Career Advisory Board Member in two broad ways.

General Information:

There is general information such as this page. There are also scheduling and tracking resources. If you click on Program Schedule Template - pdf you will get the pdf version of a simple Excel scheduling tool. It has a sample that uses movable red boxes to represent the schedule. They may send you their schedule using this tool. At the minimum they will inform you of each Career Advisory Board review sufficiently ahead of time to make a mutually acceptable schedule.

Exercise Specific Information:

There are specific resources for each Career Advisory Board review, e.g.
  • Experienced Adult Examples On the Adviser Guidance page there will be an Experienced Adult example so they can see an example more like themselves. In the Examples page there are other Experienced Adult examples.
  • Assignment Output. You will provide them with the key outputs for every exercise in the three Assignments they completed prior to the upcoming Career Advisory Board Review. For example, the 1st review will be after they finish the first three Insights Assignments: Begin at the End, Look at Self (Personality and Interests) and Look at the Past (Autobiography and Accomplishments).Click on Board Member Guidance - Review #1. This is the Board Member Guidance page for the 1st Career Advisory Board Meeting and it will open in a new tab.
  • Adviser Guidance on each exercise It will include an Introduction to the Exercise and the Steps they should be taking with you. It is in the list of Steps for the Exercise and they can also click on any of those Steps to get a full set of Instructions. They can also click on the Short Instructions page for a single page with a few sentences, examples and templates for each Step.There is an Adviser Guidance page for every Exercise that will be reviewed in Career Advisory Board Meeting #1: Begin at the End, Personality, Interests, Autobiography and Accomplishments. Below is the one for Begin at the End exercise.Click on Adviser Guidance - Begin at the End and it will open in a new Tab. Once you have reviewed it you can close the Tab.
Future Career Advisory Board Support Tools will be improved over time with feedback from the Career Advisory Board community. Some of the members may even contribute or suggest tools they have found useful.

How Can a Board Member Use this?

You can use the MyRightCareer System just as your Advisee will be using it. You can complete the Pre-Requisite Assignment, the six Insights Assignments and finally the Capstone Assignment. Since the system is self-paced you can work on these Assignments (and exercises within each Assignment) at your own pace. The bulk of the work is completing the six Insights Assignments which contain 15 Exercises. Each Exercise takes about 2.5 hours to complete. Each Exercise has multiple Steps and no Step is longer than 1 hour so you can work on this in 1 hour or shorter increments. To use the system you can click on the Experienced Adult step at the end of each page. On that page is  guidance on how you can use that Exercise to identify your own Right Career, as well as an example of someone more like you. In the Examples page there are other examples of Experienced Adults. It will not be hard for you to dialogue with your Advisee when you have just finished applying the process to your life. What are the Next Steps?
  • Optional - Learn more about the MyRightCareer Program: 1 ) Visit the Prerequisites page. It provides more detail on items such as: MyRightCareer Program, Right Career Concept, Program Approaches (College Course vs. Cafeteria), Program Content (Assignments & Exercises) and Benefits.2) Vist the Home Page and you can look at any of the six Insights Assignments (containing 13 exercises), as well as the Capstone Assignment. They are listed across the top of the page and holding your cursor over the name will produce a drop down menu showing the Exercises and Steps within each exercise.
  • Optional - Contact Don: If you would like more information send an email to Don at Don@My-Right-Career.com

item.title: Adviser Guidance - Begin at End Example
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

You should watch the Welcome to Begin at the End video at the minimum. It will give you the basic idea for this exercise and it is less than 5 minutes long.
If you want to see the instructions for on any step they are available in the menu on the right. You can also look at the Examples page and that is a good way to see what the output should be.

Begin at the End Concept

So what is the Begin at the End approach? Robert Fritz discovered it when he studied great artists. He found they used this technique to visualize their end result of playing the piano in Carnegie hall and working backwards to their current reality of playing piano in the 4th grade. They then created structural tension between their current reality and a realistic first step. Great athletic coaches use this to visualize winning the league championship and working backwards to their current reality of having just finished a losing season. They then created structural tension between their current reality and a realistic first step. They realized it they did not make it to that first step they were not going to make it to their end result.
In both cases starting with their current reality (playing piano in the 4th grade or coming off of a losing season) seems so over whelming people are often stuck and can not make any progress. The secret to these successful people is their ability to Visualize the End Result and Work Backwards and then start with some small steps.

Exercise Steps

This is an exercise I have used in the MyPlanB Workshop with people in their 30's, 40's and 50's. Except with them I let them pick the age. For example they may pick the year their last child goes to college, or the year their last child graduates from college. One way for you to understand this exercise is to do it yourself with your own life. Everyone finds it fascinating and says it provides them with a lot of insight.
Here are some basic ideas you should keep in mind as your student is doing this exercise. Below are the steps they will complete.

Age 30 Vision:

When I say Age 30 I am really recommending they choose an Age that is about 10 years in the future. Most of the students in the Program are about 20 years old so Age 30 is the example I used.
If your student is a grad student, someone who recently graduated, someone who just came back from military service, etc they may be 25 years old. You should then have them pick an appropriate age, e.g. 35 years old. In Examples take a look at Elizabeth, she just turned 25 and she used 35 as her end point.
This is not an exercise in working from today to Age 30. They should forget about today and just visualize their life at Age 30. At that time there will be more to their life than just their job (career). This exercise also allows them to complete the picture with other "Whole Person" parameters. Click on Madison's End Result and you will see an example of the document your student will end up creating. Most students will focus on these elements.
Casey is used as an example in almost all of the Exercises and she happened to visualize a career at Age 30. If you click on Casey's End Result you will get a pdf file showing Casey's description of her life at Age 30. While she is not so sure about her career choice, she does have some pretty concrete ideas about several Whole Person parameters, e.g. location and personal relationships. Casey is using the MyRightCareer Program to validate her Best Guess and if that turns out to not be true to iterate to another Best Guess.

Working Backwards:

Make sure they only picked one category (e.g. Financial, Personal Relationship, Family, Career) and did not try to do this Step with all of the elements in the Age 30 End Result Vision. With that one category they will work backwards from their Ultimate End Result (age 30) to their Intermediate End Result #3 (e.g. age 27) to their Intermediate End Result #2 (e.g. age 24) to their Intermediate End Result #1 (e.g. age 22). They can pick any ages for their Intermediate End Results that make sense for their life.
Married at Age 30: This person visualized themselves being married when they were age 30. They wanted to live together two years before getting married.
Casey's Work Backwards: Casey worked backwards from her age 30 career idea to age 22, her graduation from college.

Structural Tension:

Now they use the Structural Tension idea and create the objectives (trying to keep them around 5 objectives) that would get them from their Current Reality to their Intermediate End Result #1. If you click on Casey's Structural Tension you will get a pdf file of how Casey created a Structural Tension diagram between her Current Reality (summer between her Sophomore & Junior year) and her Intermediate End Result #1 (age 22 = graduation from college). It shows her objectives for those two years.

MyRightCareer Insights documents:

There are five MyRightCareer Insights files: one for "Be Your Best", one for "Meaning & Passion", one for "Fuel Your Economic Engine", one for "Right Career" and one for "Whole Person". This exercise has added a set of insights to each file. By the end of the MyRightCareer Program they will have accumulated a lot of insights that will assist them in identifying their Right Career and preparing their Sales Story.
These are the most important documents they will be creating during the program. Make sure they are documenting any insights, more is better, they have reached. A lot of time all they have to do is copy the insights from documents they have already created during the exercise, e.g. there is an insights document for their Age 30 Vision.
These five documents are examples of the insights Casey obtained from completing all the exercises: Begin at the End, Personality, Interests, Autobiography, Accomplishments, Strengths, Skills, Stories, Drivers, How will you Measure Your Life and Economic Engine. From these examples you can see how she has added insights with every exercise. Some of the insights might be the same, just stated in a slightly different way. Or you can have the exact same insights used in multiple circles. In fact that is what you want to see. Then you start to pick up some themes. Click on the links below to see the documents.
Casey's "Be Your Best" Insights Casey's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Casey's "Economic Engine" Insights Casey's "Right Career" Insights Casey's "Whole Person" Insights

Next Steps

Your Next Steps should be:
  • Look at an example close to your students profile. That will give you a good idea of what your student's final output should resemble.
  • See if your student needs any help while they are completing the exercise. You may be able to help them and if not send them to me.
  • Check to see their progress via the Begin at the End Checklist which you can find on the Examples page. If they don't already have it you should send them to the Examples page and suggest it as a good tool for communicating their status.
  • Once they complete this exercise, review it and then have your dialogue
  • Provide me feedback on any insights you have on the student and the Program, as well as any insights on your Adviser role.

    Feedback

    We would like your feed back on the Begin at the End Assignment. We would also like your feedback on the Adviser role and the support we are providing you. We would like you to take the SurveyMonkey survey in this section after you finish your work with your student. Most of the feedback in this survey asks you to agree or disagree with a statement. You have five levels of agreement: Strongly Disagree, Disagree, Neutral, Agree, Strongly Agree. Besides that you will have a chance to provide free form textual input. You can also send Don an email or call him at 650-400-8929.
    Create your free online surveys with SurveyMonkey , the world's leading questionnaire tool.

item.title: Board Guidance - Review #1
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Now is time for your student to discuss the results of their first three Assignments: Begin at the End, Look at Self (Personality and Interests) and Look at the Past (Autobiography and Accomplishments), with their Career Advisory Board Members. The Career Advisory Board probably never meets as a group. Instead the student will meet with each of you individually. Most of those meetings will take place over the phone and much of the content will be shared via email.
The student will start working on the next Assignment while they are having discussions with their Career Advisory Board members. Due to schedule conflicts it could take several weeks to complete this step and they can be working on the next exercise in parallel.

Multiple Approaches

You can approach this review from three basic viewpoints: Applied it to your life, Examined each Exercise and Reviewed their Exercise Output.

Applied MyRightCareer Process to Your Life

You will provide the most insightful help to your student if you complete each Assignment (and exercise within that Assignment) before your Career Advisory Board Meeting. It will not be hard to dialogue with your student when you have just finished applying the process to your life.

Examined Each Exercise

You will better understand their Exercise output if you follow the Adviser Guidance for each Exercise. It will include an Introduction to the Exercise and guidance for each Step. There are links to Examples to make it easier to understand the steps in the Exercise. Click on Adviser Guidance - Begin at the End. There is an Adviser Guidance page for every exercise.

Reviewed their Exercise Output

You can provide them a lot of help by just reviewing the Exercise output they send you. Below are examples of that output and some guidance (summarized from the Adviser Guidance page for each Exercise).

The Key Exercise Output

As supporting detail to the MyRightCareer Insights they will most likely send you files from each of the five exercises: Begin at the End, Personality, Interests, Autobiography and Accomplishments. Below are Casey's examples.

Begin at the End Assignment

  • Casey's End Result This includes her insights as well. Casey identified a possible career at Age 30, you may not have identified one and that is more normal.
  • Casey's Structural Tension This includes her insights as well.

    Look at Self Assignment

  • Personality Exercise
    This is Casey's Myers-Briggs Type Indicator and the insights she drew from her personality type. Casey's Summary of Your Myers-Briggs Results (Page 3) Casey's Career Insights
  • Interests Exercise
    Casey's Strong Interest Inventory Report (pages 1 - 9) Casey's Strong Interest Inventory Insights
  • Strong & Myers-Briggs Exercise
    Casey's Strong & Myers-Briggs Report Casey's Strong & Myers-Briggs Insights

    Look at the Past Assignment

  • Autobiography Exercise
    Casey's Autobiography Casey's Autobiography Insights
  • Accomplishments Exercise
    Casey's Top Accomplishments Casey's Accomplishments Insights

    The MyRightCareer Insights Reports

    They will send you the five MyRightCareer Insights files from their last exercise (Accomplishments): Be Your Best, Meaning & Passion, Economic Engine, Right Career and Whole Person. They only need to send you the files from the last exercise because they are cumulative files and include all their insights from the Begin at the End, Personality, Interests, Autobiography and Accomplishments exercises.
    For each area, e.g. Be Your Best, you should have a dialogue about what they have discovered about themselves relative to that element in the Right Career Venn diagram. You should also have a discussion about what they have learned about themselves as a Whole Person, the fifth file.
    Here are Casey's as an example:
    Casey's "Be Your Best" Insights Casey's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Casey's "Economic Engine" Insights Casey's "Right Career" Insights Casey's "Whole Person" Insights

    Next Steps

  • Review Meeting #2: The next Career Advisory Board Review will be after your student finishes the next three Assignments: Strengths (Talents/Strengths and Skills), Meaning (Stories, Drivers, How you will Measure Your Life) and Economic Engine (Age 30 & Age 22).
    If you are use the MyRightCareer process to identify your own right career you should now start on the Strengths (Talents/Strengths and Skills) Assignment.
  • Review Meeting #3 (Final): The final review will take place after the Capstone Project, where your student will have identified their Right Career (s), developed their Sales Story for that Right Career (s) and created a Follow-on Plan.

item.title: 1 - Focus Group Guidance
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Focus Groups are a good way to find out information in a relatively short period of time with a small investment of resources.

Exercise Assignments

Each person is only doing three exercises. With the Exercise assignments a six person group, as a whole, will have completed every Exercise and is better prepared to provide input at the Focus Group Meeting.

  • MyRightCareer Exercise Assignments

    In the table the rows are the Exercises and the columns are the Students. A student will find their column and look down it for the rows (Exercises) in which there is a number. That number is the hours it is estimated to take to complete that Exercise. Under their name is the total hours to complete the Exercises assigned to them. Right below the number of hours is the # of Exercises they have been assigned. On average each of them will be investing 10 hours spread over 3 Exercises (plus the Pre-Requisite) in the Pre Focus Meeting work. Once they are on the MyRightCareer System they can find their assigned Exercises by seeing which Assignment it is part of (these are the words across the top of the Home screen), e.g.
  • Define your Age 30 Vision is part of End
  • Personality is part of Self
  • Autobiography & Accomplishments are in Past
  • Skills & Strengths/Talents are in Strengths
  • Stories, Drivers & Measure Your Life are in Meaning
  • Age 30 Budget & Age 22 Budget are in Econ
  • Right Careers, Validate Right Careers, Sales Story & Follow-on Plan are in Capstone

    Common Duties

    As with the major Internships, the Focus Groups have the same two Common Duties - Providing Feedback and Providing Exercise Examples. Except a member of a Focus Group is only completing 3 Exercises.

    Provide Exercise Feedback

    We want your feedback on each Exercise. There will be an online survey to provide feedback on each Exercise immediately after completion. The feedback will be in two categories. Quantitative, e.g. Chose one from (Strongly Disagree, Disagree, Neutral, Agree, Strongly Agree) for a statement such as "For the skills exercise the written instructions did a good job of explaining how to do the exercise." Qualitative/Free Form, e.g. "Please provide additional explanation for your answer to the above question." We want to capture your feedback in real time because it is harder to remember what happened in an Exercise when you move on and complete the next Exercise. You are also welcome to communicate directly with Don via email or phone at any time.

    Provide Exercise Examples

    We want to use your completed exercises as examples in the Program. As you will see the Program relies heavily on examples as the way to "Explain" how to complete an exercise. Your completed exercises will be changed to disguise your identify. For example, you will be asked to pick a "stage name" and that will be used for your exercise. In addition, personal details will be edited out of your completed exercises. You will have review rights of the examples before they are used and can either request changes or refuse to have specific exercise examples used.

    Pre Focus Group Meeting Work

    Complete the Pre-Requisite Assignment

    You do not need to complete the "Intern Guidance" Exercise. You just completed the Focus Group Guidance Exercise. Click on the "Right Career Concept Overview" entry in the Sub Navigation section on the upper right and complete that Exercise. Then complete all the other Exercises in the Pre-Requisites Assignment. Note: The Pre-Requisites Assignment doesn't require you to send in any output because there is none.

    Complete your Unique Exercises

    Work on each of your Unique Exercises, providing both feedback and your exercise output.

    Focus Group Meeting

    The Focus Group Meeting will be fun and relaxed. It will take about 90 minutes, but you will need to allow 2 hours. There are very few questions and it is mainly a group discussions. Here are some questions asked in a previous Focus Group Meeting:

    Your Career

    How are you identifying your career & how close are you to identifying one

    MyRightCareer System

  • Your view of the Right Career Concept (Venn Diagram) as a model
  • Navigation: What experiences did you have navigating within the MyRightCareer System, e.g. - Within PreRequisite - moving from Step to Step (e.g. Right Career Concept, Program Approach) - Within an Exercise - moving from Step 1 to Step X - Overall - Finding an Assignment/Exercise, Examples, Templates
  • Instructions: - What was your experience with Short Instructions and Full Instructions. - What do you think about the value of Examples and Templates
  • PreRequisite - Explain how it helped you understand the Right Career Concept, the overall system, the Exercises - Explain how it prepared you to do Assignments & Exercises
  • Assignments & Exercises - Describe your experience with your Exercises - Do you think you could choose a subset of the six Insights Assignments and still identify your Right Career? - Provide your vision of what would happen if you completed all the Assignments
  • Goal Achievement: How well do you believe the MyRightCareer program will help you to identify your prospective career?

    Focus Group

    How can we improve the Pre Meeting Work and the Focus Meeting itself

    If You Need Help

    The MyRightCareer System is designed to be self-paced, but the version you are using is in Alpha so you may find it is not "perfect".
  • Confusing Instructions: If you find something is stopping you from advancing because if is not clear please contact Don
  • Errors: If you find errors, e.g. Page Not Found, that stop you from proceeding also contact Don
  • General Feedback: For most other feedback you can wait and provide it via the SurveyMonkey survey at the end of each exercise. But you are always welcome to provide you feedback directly to Don
    You can contact Don by email (Don@My-Right-Career.com) or by phone 650-400-8929).

item.title: Instructions-Success Built to Last
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

This is a short course on the Success Built to Last research. It provides the research findings that support the Meaning & Passion circle in the Right Career Venn diagram. • Create meaning and passion in your life • Be your best • Fuel the “economic engine” that leads to financial security . . . . . Click on each topic to see a video clip from two of the co-authors of Success Built to Last as they explain the findings of their research. These are video clips from their TV program. This course is about 20 minutes of that hour long program.

  • Introduction

    People who achieve lasting success are more rare and the authors set out to find out what sets them apart. Hear the author's explain how they found these people and discovered their secrets to building success that lasts.

  • What is Success

    These 200 people look at success differently.

  • Won't Settle

    Hear the author's talk about why these people won't settle for anything that doesn't provide them with meaning. Also hear Herb Kelleher, the co-founder of Southwest Airlines, as he talks about the role passion plays in success.

  • Passion & Love

    The authors relate Maya Angelou's (author, poet & performer) view of the role passion plays in success. They also describe how this view is also shared by enduring successful CEO's. Hear Warren Buffet explain why you shouldn't wait to pursue your Right Career.

    Summary

    The author's research lead to two main conclusions: What you do must have Meaning, i.e. what you do must matter deeply to you. It’s something you’re so passionate about that you lose all track of time when you do it. In fact it may not feel like work at all. It seduces you to the point where you lose interest in everything else.
    The bad news is that it’s really dangerous not to do what you love. The harsh truth is that if you don’t love what you’re doing, you’ll lose to someone who does. Your co-workers or competitors who love their work will gladly work longer hours, think about work 24/7, try more things, come up with more great ideas and get better opportunities than people who only do things for a living.
    While you should take each module in the order shown, each one stands alone so they could be taken at different times during the day or on different days. The total length of the Success Built to Last course is approximately 20 minutes.

    Application to Your Life

    Create a short document describing how you believe you can apply what you learned to your life. Click on Edward's Success Built to Last Insights.

item.title: Step 2 - Validate Right Career
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

There are many ways to Validate the career (s) you identified are your Right Career (s). At the minimum you need to do the following two. First you need to search for more information about that right career and build up a storehouse of knowledge. Second you need to identify some people in that field who would allow you to have an Informational Interview. One of the reasons for doing the first task, research the field, is to appear knowledgeable and interested when you have your Information Interviews.

Research

Informational Interviews

item.title: Career Counselor: Bill Gates or Steve Jobs?
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: College students want to know what courses and majors will give them an edge in their careers. But the choices are not always clear, even if you are taking advice from Bill Gates or Steve Jobs. In a talk to the nation's governors earlier this month, Mr. Gates emphasized work-related learning, arguing that education investment should be aimed at academic disciplines and departments that are "well-correlated to areas that actually produce jobs." If this was not music to the ears of advocates of the humanities, they quickly found a soul mate in Steve Jobs. At an event unveiling new Apple products, Mr. Jobs said: "It's in Apple's DNA that technology alone is not enough -- it's technology married with liberal arts, married with the humanities, that yields us the result that makes our heart sing and nowhere is that more true than in these post-PC devices." What do we know about the relationship between college studies and majors and future employment? What gets you a good first job and what leads to career success? Click on Room for Debate to see a document with 8 expert's views of the right majors for future career success. This is a multiple page document.

item.title: Success Built to Last
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: "Success Built to Last" forms the foundation for the Meaning & Passion circle. The authors (Jerry Porras, Stewart Emery, and Mark Thompson) based their results on the video interviews of 200 successful people, from CEOs to Nobel Laureates to community leaders. They found to achieve true lasting success what you do must have meaning, i.e. what you do must matter deeply to you. They also found it is dangerous to not do what you love because you will lose out to colleagues and competitors who truly love their work. There are at least four video clips that you should find interesting at the link below: "What is Success", "What Successful People are Missing", "Make More Mistakes" and "Be a Good One". Check out the videos!

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Below are examples from this Exercise: Generic Whole Person, College Students, Recent Graduates and Experienced Adults.

Success Built to Last - Book Summary

Success Built to Last Book Summary

Casey - End Sophomore Year

Coming Soon

Edward - End Junior Year

Edward's Success Built to Last Insights

Experienced Adults

Below are examples that can be of value to an Experienced Adult who wants to use the MyRightCareer System for their own life or just see examples more like themselves to improve their ability to be an Adviser. To get started using the MyRightCareer System for your own career click on the “Experienced Adult” heading in the Sub Navigation panel on the right. College students may also find these examples useful because they show 1) how this technique can be used the rest of your life and 2) some interesting examples of how someone more your parent's age used the approach.

item.title: Experienced Adult-Begin at End
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

You are going to use the same instructions and templates the students use to complete this exercise. The differences from the student are:
  • You can also use the Experienced Adult examples described on this page and shown on the Examples page
  • You will get some specific guidance as to how to change the Age 30 Vision to a more appropriate age for your situation.

Experienced Adult Examples

Below are two examples that can be of value to you when using the MyRightCareer System for your own life. Bud's example has much more detail than Mary's example. The amount of detail you put into your output is entirely up to you. There are more Experienced Adult examples at the end of the Examples page, which you can access from the Sub Navigation Panel on the right. If you want to complete this use the same templates the students use. End Result Mary's Time Line. She selected the year her twins leave for college. This is 5 years from her current situation. Mary's End Result She picked six key parameters. Bud's Time Line. He selected the year his son, his youngest child, graduated from high school. This was 7 years in the future and also the time his daughter was scheduled to graduate from college. Bud's End Result He picked eight key parameters. Bud's 2013 Vision Board you will see it basically has one picture for each of the nine items in the End Result document. Working Backwards Mary's Work Backwards: Mary worked backwards from her Ultimate End Result (Age 56) to her Current Reality (Age 51). Bud's Work Backwards: He worked backwards from his End Result, his son's graduation from high school, to the Current Reality (single parent with a 5th grader and a 9th grader). Structural Tension Mary's Structural Tension: Mary created a document showing the relationship between her Current Reality and her Intermediate End Result #1. Mary's Structural Tension Objectives: Mary created five Objectives she feels she needs to achieve to move from her Current Reality to her Intermediate End Result #1. Bud's Structural Tension: Bud created a document showing the relationship between his Current Reality and his Intermediate End Result #1. Bud's 2013 Personal Situation Vision Board. He shows just one of the items, his personal situation, and creates a Vision of what he wants it to be when his son graduates from high school. Bud's Structural Tension Objectives: Bud created five Objectives he feels he needs to achieve to move from his Current Reality to his Intermediate End Result #1, for just his Personal Situation. This is the first step toward the Vision displayed on the Vision Board - having someone next to him at his son's high school graduation.

Experienced Adult Instructions

Instructions and Templates

You should use the same templates the students use. Previously the participants used an Excel spreadsheet but I have found most people do better with Word. Plus there are good instructions for those new Word templates and you should follow the same instructions the students are using.

Major Difference - Age X vs. Age 30 Vision

This is an exercise that is used with people in their 30's, 40's, 50's and 60's. Except they pick the age. For example they may pick the year their last child goes to college, or the year their last child graduates from college. Some people just pick a year, e.g. when I turn 50 or when I turn 60. Everyone finds this exercise fascinating and says it provides them with a lot of insight.

Next Steps

Your Next Steps should be:

Choose your Instruction approach

  • Short Instructions: If you are the type of person who only needs a very minor amount of explanation and some examples the Short Instructions Approach will probably work just fine. It is basically reading a couple of sentences of instructions and using examples to do your work. You can also jump to a full instructions version of any step if you find you need more help.
  • Full Instructions: If you would like a full set of instructions, which includes the approximately 6 minute video and instructions with multiple examples integrated into the text, then the Full Instructions Approach will work better.
  • Hybrid: You can start with the Short Instructions and then when you feel one of the Steps requires more instructions you can switch to the Full Instructions approach for that Step. After that step you can switch back to the Short Instructions approach for the rest of the Instructions.

Get Started with the Exercise

  • Short Instructions: Click on "Short Instructions" in the Sub Navigation menu on the upper right
  • Full Instructions: Click on "Step 0 - Introduction" in the Sub Navigation menu on the upper right

item.title: Experienced Adult-Personality
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

You are going to use the same instructions and templates the students use to complete this exercise. The differences from the student are:
  • You can also use the Experienced Adult examples described on this page and shown on the Examples page
  • You will get some specific guidance as to how to change the Age 30 Vision to a more appropriate age for your situation.

Experienced Adult Examples

Below are two examples that can be of value to an Adviser or Career Advisory Board Member if you want to use the MyRightCareer System for your own life. Matt (ENTJ) and Bud (INTJ) will be more relevant than the college student examples. You will notice Matt and Bud's output is slightly different than the students. There are more Experienced Adult examples at the end of the Examples page, which you can access from the Sub Navigation Panel on the right. If you want to complete this use the same templates the students use.

Bud - INTJ

I (Introversion) - Clarity is Moderate: I focus on the inner world of ideas and impressions N (Intuition) - Clarity is Clear: I take in information from patterns and the big picture and focus on future possibilities T (Thinking) - Clarity is Moderate, almost Clear: I make decisions based on logic and on objective analysis of cause and effect J (Judging) - Clarity is Very Clear: I like a planned and organized approach, plus I want to have things settled Bud's Myers-Briggs Report Bud's "Do What You Are" Report Bud's Personality Insights Bud's Myers-Briggs Self Assessment Bud's Career Insights

Matt - ENTJ

E (Extraversion) - Clarity is Very Clear: I focus on the outer world of people and activity N (Intuition) - Clarity is Moderate: I take in information from patterns and the big picture and focus on future possibilities T (Thinking) - Clarity is Slight: I make decisions based on logic and on objective analysis of cause and effect J (Judging) - Clarity is Slight: I like a planned and organized approach, plus I want to have things settled Matt's Myers-Briggs Report Matt's "Do What You Are" Report Matt's Personality Insights

Experienced Adult Instructions

Instructions and Templates

You should use the same instructions and templates the students use.

Differences

Combined Myers-Brigss and Strong Interest Inventory Assessment The combined Myers-Brigss and Strong Interest Inventory Assessment is $99. You should be able to take it from your college's Career Center, most of them are eager to support Alumni. If not then click on "Step 1 - Take Assessments" in the Sub Navigation panel on the right for instructions on paying for it yourself. Many people have taken a Myers-Briggs assessment sometime in their career. If so compare your previous Type (if you still have the assessment or can remember it) to this one. I bet they are the same. "Do What You Are" Report If your Career Center does not provide the “Do What You Are” Report or will not support an Alumni, you will have to pay for it ($29). If they don't provide the report then click on "Step 2 - "Do What You Are" in the Sub Navigation panel on the right for instructions.

Next Steps

Your Next Steps should be:

Choose your Instruction approach

  • Short Instructions: If you are the type of person who only needs a very minor amount of explanation and some examples the Short Instructions Approach will probably work just fine. It is basically reading a couple of sentences of instructions and using examples to do your work. You can also jump to a full instructions version of any step if you find you need more help.
  • Full Instructions: If you would like a full set of instructions, which includes the approximately 6 minute video and instructions with multiple examples integrated into the text, then the Full Instructions Approach will work better.
  • Hybrid: You can start with the Short Instructions and then when you feel one of the Steps requires more instructions you can switch to the Full Instructions approach for that Step. After that step you can switch back to the Short Instructions approach for the rest of the Instructions.

Get Started with the Exercise

  • Short Instructions: Click on "Short Instructions" in the Sub Navigation menu on the upper right
  • Full Instructions: Click on "Step 0 - Introduction" in the Sub Navigation menu on the upper right

item.title: What should I do with my life
item.dc:creator: admin

item.title: Rare Find
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The best hope of spotting these hidden winners was to steal a quick peek at the bottom of the résumé.
At Google, Todd Carlisle is director of staffing. In 2005, he began an experiment, collecting factors that might distinguish between hiring great employees and picking the wrong people. Within a few months, Carlisle had some answers. Most supposed markers of success turned out to be mirages.
The best hope of spotting these hidden winners, Carlisle came to believe, was to steal a quick peek at the bottom of the résumé. He became known as the man who analyzed them “upside down.” Now, when Carlisle pulls one up on his laptop—which happens dozens of times a day—he begins by tapping the “Page Down” key a couple times until he reaches the final entries.
Then he scrutinizes the loose ends of candidates’ bios. “I want to know their stories,” Carlisle explained one morning. “I want to know what these people are all about.” In a moment, he might start hunting for the classic markers of competence: work history, education, credentials, and the like. But first he wants to see if some special, rare attribute could point the way to greatness.
<h3><a href="http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/the-rare-find-reinventing-recruiting-10132011.html" target="_blank">The Rare Find Business Week Article</a></h3> <ul></ul>
Excerpted from George Anders's The Rare Find: Spotting Exceptional Talent Before Everone Else.

item.title: Experienced Adult-AutoBio
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

You are going to use the same instructions and templates the students use to complete this exercise. The differences from the student is you can also use the Experienced Adult example described on this page, as well as the ones shown on the Examples page.

Experienced Adult Examples

Bud's example will be more relevant than the college student examples. If you want to complete this use the same templates the students use. There are more Experienced Adult examples at the end of the Examples page, which you can access from the Sub Navigation Panel on the right. If you want to complete this use the same templates the students use. Bud's Autobiography Bud's Autobiography Insights Bud's Transitions and Insights. Bud included his Transition Insights in this file. Bud's Career Decisions and Mistakes. Bud did an extensive analysis of all 17 of his career decisions, starting with which college to attend. He narrowed them down to major (9 of the 17) and really major (6 of the 17). For each career decision he looked at the major alternative (s) he considered. Then he documented the Mistakes he has made and the Insights he has gained.

Experienced Adult Instructions

Instructions and Templates

You should use the same instructions and templates the students use.

Difference - Career Decisions and Mistakes Exercise

This exercise isn’t really useful for a college student, but is very valuable for a mid-life professional.
  • 1st you need to itemize all of the career decisions you feel you have made in your life. You will notice in Bud's example above he decided his first career decision was choosing the college to attend. He also identified 17 career decisions.
  • 2nd you need to narrow your career decisions down to the major ones. In Bud's example above he decided 9 of the 17 were Major career decisions. Because he still had quite a few Major career decisions he went one step further and identified the really major career decisions (6 of the 17).
  • 3rd for each of the major alternatives look at the alternative (s) you considered when you made that career decision. Think about how you made that career decision.
  • 4th you need to document the career Mistakes you have made and the Insights you have gained from your Career Decisions.
Most likely you will face more career decisions in the future and this will give you some insights into your decision criteria and approach.

Next Steps

Your Next Steps should be:

Choose your Instruction approach

  • Short Instructions: If you are the type of person who only needs a very minor amount of explanation and some examples the Short Instructions Approach will probably work just fine. It is basically reading a couple of sentences of instructions and using examples to do your work. You can also jump to a full instructions version of any step if you find you need more help.
  • Full Instructions: If you would like a full set of instructions, which includes the approximately 6 minute video and instructions with multiple examples integrated into the text, then the Full Instructions Approach will work better.
  • Hybrid: You can start with the Short Instructions and then when you feel one of the Steps requires more instructions you can switch to the Full Instructions approach for that Step. After that step you can switch back to the Short Instructions approach for the rest of the Instructions.

Get Started with the Exercise

  • Short Instructions: Click on "Short Instructions" in the Sub Navigation menu on the upper right
  • Full Instructions: Click on "Step 0 - Introduction" in the Sub Navigation menu on the upper right

Bud's All Accomplishments List Bud's Top 7 Accomplishments List

Experienced Adult Instructions

Instructions and Templates

You should use the same instructions and templates the students use.

Difference

You will notice the experienced adults had to choose which of many accomplishments (e.g. Bud had 10 from elementary school through grad school, 41 from grad school to age 44 and 4 that were purely personal, e.g. becoming a father) they want to call their Major Accomplishments. Bud then chose 7 Major Accomplishments out of all of that large group. Most students have the opposite problem, trying to find enough accomplishments to reach the suggested total.

item.content:encoded:
Introduction

You are going to use the same instructions and templates the students use to complete this exercise. The differences from the student is you can also use the Experienced Adult example described on this page, as well as the ones shown on the Examples page.

Experienced Adult Examples

Bud's example will be more relevant than the college student examples. If you want to complete this use the same templates the students use. There are more Experienced Adult examples at the end of the Examples page, which you can access from the Sub Navigation Panel on the right. If you want to complete this use the same templates the students use. Skills List Bud used the same O*NET system the college students use to identify his skills, i.e. he picked them from the list provided by the O*NET system. Occupations List The O*NET system then produced a list of Occupations that use those skills. The list starts with the occupations that use the most of his skills and then goes down. Bud highlighted in yellow the occupations of most interest to him. CEO Skills Required vs. Bud's Skills The O*NET System produces a report showing the skills required for the CEO role and then shows which of those Bud has. There is a similar report for the Treasurer-Controller role. One of the skills Bud lacks for both roles is Active Listening. CEO Summary Report The O*NET System has a comprehensive report for each Occupation. It has links at the end to other information about that Occupation. Insights Bud created his insights from this exercise
